editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT REVEREND FATHER IN GOD, TOBIE, BY GODS GRACE Bi≈øhop of Dure≈øme, his ≈øpeciall good Lord.
div.p:
THE la≈øt Se≈ø≈øion of the Parliament, my good Lorde, I an≈øwered a certain petition then diuulged and printed by the Ma≈øters and teachers of Popi≈øh religion: and this, I had well hoped, would haue ≈øati≈øfied their di≈øciples and folowers, ≈øeeing their learned leaders ≈øo ≈øilent and vnable to replie. But I perceiue that the common ≈øaying now prooueth true, That many ≈øchollers Cicer. Epi≈øt. famil lib. 9. ad varronem. pa≈ø≈øe their Ma≈øters. For if they had not excelled their teachers in immode≈øty, they woulde not haue rubbed ouer that ru≈øtie ≈øtuffe, which their betters are a≈øhamed to bring againe vpon the ≈øtage: and if they had not pa≈ø≈øed them in boldne≈ø≈øe and importunitie, they would haue forborne to importune his Maie≈øtie and the ≈øtate further, in matters formerlie, for ≈øuch graue and important con≈øiderations, mo≈øt worthilie reiected. And yet I ≈øpeake not this, to the intent to clear their ma≈øters. For be≈øide that this ≈øeemeth a deui≈øe
of their Ma≈øters the Ma≈ø≈øeprie≈øtes and Iebu≈øites, that make others to ≈øolicite their forelorne cau≈øe, Chry≈øo≈øtom homil. 43. op. imperf. in Math. telleth vs, that the impiety of the ≈øchollers is to be imputed to the ma≈øters.

The argument of both petitions is one in effecte, and therefore much more needeth not to be ≈øaid now then that which is formerly aun≈øwered to the Ma≈ø≈øeprie≈øts. Yet becau≈øe all haue not ≈øeene the former petition and an≈øwer, nor vnder≈øtood their gunpowder, and rebellious practi≈øes; and the≈øe Lay, or rather lame Romane Catholikes, ≈øeeme to ≈øtand more vpon their loyaltie, then the other; I thought it not ami≈ø≈øe, after this late di≈øcouery of their mo≈øt horrible trea≈øons, particulerly to examine this di≈øcour≈øe al≈øo, and with marginall Glo≈ø≈øes to poynt to the fooleries of their text, which notwith≈øtanding I would not haue all ≈øimple papi≈øts take, as ≈øpoken to theÃÑ≈øelues. for my meaning was to touch only the≈øe Petitioners, and ≈øuch as ≈øub≈øcribe this factious Petition.

Much adoe we haue about toleration of popi≈øh religion, but we may ≈øay, as Saluianus lib. 7. de prouidentia ≈øaid ≈øometime in another ca≈øe: vtinam hoc remedium malorum, & non diuturna toleratio. I would this toleration, which they de≈øire, were a remedie of their pretended euills, and not rather a long continued toleration of mi≈øchiefes, and that both in the Church and ≈øtate. For why, I be≈øeech you, may we not ≈øo ≈øay, ≈øeeing nothing can be granted, that is either more derogatorie to Gods honor, or more preiudiciall to the Kings maie≈øty and ≈øtate, as hath in part appeared by this late attempt, and as God willing it ≈øhall at large, with mo≈øte
inuincible arguments, be demon≈øtrated?

This my di≈øcour≈øe, mo≈øt reuerend Father, I pre≈øent to your Honor, as a pledg of my loue, and an acknowledgment of your Lord≈øhips fauours towards me: and the rather, that both your Lord≈øhip and al true Chri≈øtians truelie zealous for the cau≈øe of true pietie, and ≈øtudious of the ≈øafety of their countrie, may thereby vnder≈øtand, how much it importeth them all to concur in repre≈ø≈øing ≈øuch notorious in≈øolency, & factious cour≈øes. The≈øe men, they are like the heretiks, of whom Irenaeus lib. 5. aduer≈ø: haere≈ø. ≈øpeaketh, which being blind in matters of truth, did contradict their own ≈øaluation. Caecutientes circa veritatem, ≈øaith he, ≈øuae contradicunt ≈øaluti. But pious governours will neither neglect the ≈øafety of religion & the ≈øtate, nor of the≈øe conteÃÑtious gaine≈øayers of truth, if they doo not wilfully ≈øhut their eares to the truth, and their eies to the light, and carele≈øly neglecte the re≈øtraint of the vnderminers both of the Parliament hou≈øe, and whole State. Wherefore referring the≈øe matters next to Gods prouideÃÑce, to the zealous care of our ≈øuperiors, I commend this worke and my ≈øelfe to your Lord≈øhip, and your Lord≈øhips pro≈øperous e≈øtate, to the fauour of the almighty. London, this fir≈øt of Ianuarie, Anno. 1605.

div.head: To the Chri≈øtian Reader.
div.p: I DOE not beleeue, gentle reader, that many lay papists will ≈øub≈øcribe this petition, albeit pretended to bee framed and exhibited by all of them to the King. It were a matter too ≈øawcy, for wi≈øe, and ciuill men to challenge the king of breach of promi≈øe, as they do pag. 8: and too pre≈øumptuous to rayle on religion publiquelie profe≈ø≈øed, and the profe≈ø≈øors thereof, to the Kings face, as they do in diuers places. Neither do I think, that all are ≈øo fooli≈øh, as to make them≈øelues pledges and ho≈øtages for their Ma≈ø≈øeprie≈øts, ≈øuffering ≈øuch ≈ølippery coÃÑpanioÃÑs to dominere in their hou≈øes, to confer with their wiues & daughters, to wa≈øt their e≈øtate, while they haue no Counterbond from them, either for the others good behauiour, or theire owne ≈øecuritie. This I am well a≈ø≈øured, that what ≈øoeuer is pretended, this petition neuer came Originally from the heades of lay papi≈øtes. For neyther may ≈øuch men withoute licence, reade Caluines In≈øtitutions, nor Luthers bookes, nor other di≈øcour≈øes written by men of our ≈øide: nor may they take vpon them to di≈øcour≈øe of Religion, as the Authors of this petition doe.

I wold therfore pray the ≈øimpler ≈øort of plain meaning Papi≈øts, not to take what ≈øoeuer is ≈øharpely ≈øpoken again≈øt the Ma≈ø≈øe Prie≈øtes ma≈øked vnder the name of lay papi≈øts, and the ≈øole deui≈øers of this
petition, and their abherents, the Authors of many trea≈øons and mi≈øchiefes, as ≈øpoken or meant again≈øt them≈øelues, and all ≈øeduced ≈øimple ≈øoules. And again≈øt ≈øuch as ≈øo violently run a cour≈øe again≈øt truth, and ≈øeek to blow vp the King and State: I doubte not, but all indifferent men will e≈øteeme my ≈øpeech moderate, and this kinde of dealing most fitting and conuenient. What? ≈øhall vncircumcized Phili≈øtims raile at the people of God, and ≈øeeke our destruction; and ≈øhall not true Chri≈øtians be permitted liberty to repre≈ø≈øe theire in≈øolency, to countermine their vndermining trea≈øons, and freely to defend the truth?

When them≈øelues do publi≈øh their petitions, they may not refu≈øe to haue them publiquelie examined; and no rea≈øon haue they to complaine of wrong, ≈øeeing them≈øelues thus handled, when notwith≈øtanding their wicked intentions, they put forth their Apologyes, reque≈øts, and di≈øcour≈øes into other mens handes, as if they were mo≈øt loyall and hone≈øt men.

Hitherto they haue abu≈øed the worlde with a fal≈øe pretence of antiquitie, and fal≈øelie chalenged to them≈øelues the name and title of Catholiques. They doe al≈øo before ≈øuch, as are ignorant of matters of ≈øtate, ≈øtand vpon termes of loyalty, and loue of theire Prince and country. But now that we are ≈øo farre vrged, we ≈øhall God willing, make it appeare, that their Popi≈øh deui≈øes are nothing but a pack of nouelties latelie brought into the Romi≈øh church, & that their Religion is full of here≈øies, impieties and bla≈øphemies: and la≈øtly that diuers of their practi≈øes are full of Salt peter, and mo≈øt dangerous to the ≈øtate: and that their importunate de≈øires are repugnaÃÑt both to rea≈øons of religion & ≈øtate, and al≈øo to modest and ciuill cariage.

My ≈øole reque≈øt to thee ≈øhall be, that thou wolde≈øt be plea≈øe to compare our an≈øwer with the lay papi≈øts petition, and to iudge according to proofes, We ≈øeeke for trueth, we defend the Kings prerogatiue and ≈øtate. Let no man therfore ≈øhut his eies again≈øt that light, by which we may ≈øee truth, nor bee carele≈ø≈øe in matters ≈øo nerelye touching the ≈øafety of the King and ≈øtate, neither let any papi≈øt bee offended with vs, while we ≈øeeke his ≈øaluation. Non ideo vobis di≈øpliceamus, ≈øaith Saint Augu≈øtine to certein Donati≈øts, epi≈øt.
204. ad Donatum, quia reuocamus erraÃÑtes, & quaerimus perditos. and ≈øo wee ≈øay al≈øo to the ≈øimple, and abu≈øed papi≈øts, Let vs not di≈øplea≈øe you, becau≈øe we ≈øeek to call you from your errors, and to gaine that which is lo≈øt, We doe not hate you, as our Countrimen, but we dete≈øt your errors, being humorou≈øly affected to forraine ≈øuper≈øtition. In ≈øpeaking al≈øo for common peace and ≈øafety we ≈øeek your peace. The petitioners ≈øay, they are re≈øolued and pretend rea≈øon of their re≈øolution. But nothing is more fanta≈øtical or fooli≈øh, then to re≈øolue vpon fal≈øe ≈øuppo≈øitions, and to build without firme foundation. neither is any thing more ≈øotti≈øh then to ≈øeek that, which being granted, would turne to theire di≈øhonoure and hurt, if not destruction.

To confirme the weake, and to recall tho≈øe which goe a≈øtray wee haue done our best endeuour: wee haue al≈øo defended the honor of religion, his maiestie, and the state, as became vs. The re≈øt wee referre to gods grace; be≈øeeching him, ≈øo to enlighten all chri≈øtian mens heartes with the knowledg of his eternall truth, that not onelie the profe≈ø≈øors of religion may stand firm again≈øt the glozing per≈øwa≈øions of ≈øeducing and ≈øeditions Iebu≈øites and Ma≈ø≈øe-Prie≈øts: but al≈øo ≈øuch, as encline too much to error and ≈øuper≈øtition, and nowe ≈øeeme malcontented, maye be gathered into the true Church, and ≈øhew them≈øelues true ≈øubiects, embracing truth and per≈øeuering therein to their liues end.

div.head: A BRIEFE EXAMINATION, OF The Lay Papi≈øtes late petition, directed to his royall Maie≈øtie. Anno. 1604.
Chapter 1. The re≈øolution of the petition apologeticall of the Lay papi≈øts, together with a ≈øomme of the an≈øwer, made vnto it.
div.p: COmmonly we ≈øee by experience, that excu≈øes going before accu≈øations, doo argue a ≈øecret confe≈ø≈øion of the faultes of guiltie con≈øciences. Jf nothing els did ≈øhew it; yet this, and diuers other petitions, and Apologies directed by diuers Ma≈ø≈øe prie≈øts, and Papi≈øts vnto his royall maie≈øtie, who neither chargeth them, nor proceedeth again≈øte them for tho≈øe matters, which they goe about to couer and excu≈øe, do prooue it ≈øufficiently. For what rea≈øon haue they to make ≈øo many defen≈øes and excu≈øes, if they did not knowe in their con≈øciences, that there are certaine matters, wherewith they de≈øerue to bee charged? doo the defendants v≈øe to make their an≈øwers before the accu≈øers exhibit their bills, or articles?

But ≈øuppo≈øe their con≈øciences were cleare: yet their wordes do argue plainly, that neither for their faith towards god, nor for their fidelity to his maie≈øtie, they ≈øtand vpright in the common reputation of their countrimen. For if they did, what ≈øhould they need to publi≈øh ≈øuch Apologies, wherein they pretend to giue his Maie≈øtie an accompt of their beleefe and religion, and a full and ample ≈øecuritie and ≈øatisfaction of their fidelities and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion? againe, if their cau≈øe were ≈øo cleere, why doo not Ma≈ø≈øeprie≈øts come foorth, and ≈øhew them≈øelues? and why ≈øhould the lay Papi≈øts be ≈øo ≈øparing in giuing the King his prerogatiue, and ≈øo laui≈øh in a≈øcribing his right to the Pope? La≈øtly what meant Percie and his companions, to attempt ≈øo bloodie an execution, and all papites to pray for the good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of matters de≈øigned? To forbeare to ≈øpeake of the quality of their cau≈øe, which we ≈øhall haue more occa≈øion to do hereafter, fir≈øt we are to vnder≈øtand, what their intention is, in this their Apologeticall Epi≈øtle, and next what forme they keepe in their proceedings. Their reque≈øt is fir≈øt, that penall lawes made heretofore again≈øt Ma≈ø≈øeprie≈øtes, recu≈øantes, and their abettors, may be either reuer≈øed or ≈øu≈øpended. And next, that Popi≈øh religion and the teachers thereof, may be tolerated vpon a certaine forme of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. And la≈øtly, that his maie≈øty wold be plea≈øed to accompt Papi≈øts for his good ≈øubiects, and to ≈øu≈øpect the re≈øt. Matters all of verye hard di≈øge≈øtion, and verie difficult to be proued, or granted.

Yet what dare they not attempt, to obtaine a toleration of their wicked abu≈øes? fir≈øt they threaten the King, Chapter 3: with an intimation of their numbers, forces and intelligences bothe at home and abroade: not forgetting to bragge of their qualities and merites. Next they alleadge certaine rea≈øons of their re≈øolution in popi≈øhe religion. Thirdly, which to vs ≈øeemeth very admirable, con≈øidering their manifold rebellions and trea≈øons again≈øt their princes & couÃÑ tries both in England and el≈øewhere, and the late horrible trea≈øon then in brewing, they ≈øtand vpon high termes of theire loyall carriage and fidelity. Fourthly, albeit the ≈øame be without
the coÃÑpa≈ø≈øe of their apologeticall petition, yet they run out into a long accu≈øation of the profe≈ø≈øors of true religion, therein inuoluing his maie≈øty & the gouernors of the ≈øtate, & as it were ridiculou≈øly making them to an≈øwer, that mu≈øt be their iudges. Lastly they offer a form of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øioÃÑ, & preteÃÑd to giue vs ≈øufficient ≈øecurity for the Kings life, & for the pre≈øeruation of the ≈øtate of which the fir≈øt declareth their obedience to be very bare & onelie voluntarie, the ≈øecond argueth theire pride to bee in≈øupportable, which vndertake to capitulate with the King, and thinke their worde and bonde ≈øufficiente for the ≈øecuritie of ≈øuch a king and ≈øtate. But wee mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that nowe they were conceiting theire horrible trea≈øons, and that they ment to burne their bonds, and the parties to whom they ≈øtood obliged, This is the ≈øub≈øtance of their pleading. For the better garni≈øhing whereof they propo≈øe rea≈øons, fir≈øte of their former ≈øilence, & next of the breach of their ≈øilence in this petitioÃÑ apologeticall: albeit we haue iu≈øt cau≈øe to wonder, how they can well ≈øpeak of ≈øilence, when ≈øo many of their con≈øorts, haue neuer cea≈øed their babling and ≈øcribling about this obiect & how they dare preteÃÑd rea≈øons of this petitioÃÑ, that is ≈øo deuoid of weight, rea≈øon, & wi≈øedom, Be≈øide the≈øe rea≈øoÃÑs Iohn Lecey commeth in, with a prologue in commendation of the actours in this Pageant and certaine bani≈øhed Ma≈ø≈øe-Pre≈øtes ≈øtaÃÑd in the rereward with an epilogue to the Lords of his maie≈øties couÃÑ≈øel, accu≈øing them of iniu≈øtice & hard dealing, which ≈øome confe≈ø≈øe in part to bee true. for if they had been iu≈øtlye dealt with all; then had they been exequuted for their trecherous practi≈øes, and felonies, for which diuers of them ≈øtood by lawe condemned, and not ≈øent awaye to rayle vpon ≈øuch, as ≈øhewed mercie and fauoure to them. And this is the corps, the deuaÃÑt, derrier, & al the coÃÑteÃÑts of this lame petitioÃÑ apologetical, framed, as is ≈øayd, by lay Papi≈øts, or rather in theire names by certein ma≈ø≈øe-Prie≈øts. For an≈øwer wherof, although no further an≈øwere needeth, then that, which alreadye hath beene made to their good ma≈øters, vrging the ≈øame things in diuers of theire libels, di≈øcour≈øes and petitions, wee purpo≈øe by Gods
grace to hold this cour≈øe, Fir≈øt it ≈øhall be declared, that toleration of fal≈øe religions is repugnant to rules of religion and holy ≈øcripture, and next that it is contrary to al Chri≈øtian policie and rea≈øon. Thirdly that the Papi≈øtes them≈øelues in places where they commaund, deny all toleration of other Religions then that which they profe≈ø≈øe them≈øelues. Furthermore lea≈øte the Papi≈øts mighte excepte, that the≈øe allegations doe nothing concerne theire cau≈øe, it ≈øhall be further proued, that poperie is a fal≈øe, idolatrous, hereticall, new, and bla≈øphemous religion, and not onelie enemie to kings and princes, but al≈øo greeuous to all Chri≈øtians. Finally, lea≈øt any of the≈øe petitioners ≈øhoulde ≈øwell with pride and thinke, that with his greate eloquence he were able either to iu≈øtify the cau≈øe of popi≈øh Religion, or to make good his rea≈øons for toleration therof; we haue thought good, not onelie to glo≈ø≈øe the text, but al≈øo to examine the prologues, rea≈øons, epilogues, defen≈øes, accu≈øations and whole pleadings of our aduer≈øaries throughout their whole apologeticall petitioÃÑ, Tu leno haere≈øis Arrianae ≈øaith Lucifer in his apology for Athana≈øius, cunctos fieri cupis con≈øacrilegos tuos. So wee may ≈øay of the≈øe petitioners, that while, like bawdes they ≈øet forth the whore of Babylon, & her whori≈øh religion, they ≈øeek to make vs partakers with them of theire ≈øacriledge and impietye. HItherto the≈øe petttioners haue well di≈ø≈øembled theire violent humors, pretending only humilitie ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion; and offring in termes to giue ≈øati≈øfaction and coÃÑtentment to his maie≈øty. Fir≈øt they go aboute to per≈øwade his maie≈øty, that as many of his ≈øubiects in England and Jreland are papi≈øtes as profe≈ø≈øors of true religion. they woulde perca≈øe ≈øay the ≈øame of Scotland but that theire con≈øciience told them contrary. But fir≈øt they mu≈øt ≈øhew, that Papi≈øts houlding with the pope are true ≈øubiects, before they place them in the nuÃÑ ber of the Kings true ≈øubiects. next they mu≈øt bring forth the rolls of the mini≈øters of papi≈øts, and name them, or el≈øe no man wil beleue them. For in Ireland, how≈øoeuer the commoÃÑ fort reteineth ≈øome popi≈øh ceremonies the number of that znuer≈øtand the principall grounds and doctrines of popery is very ≈ølander, In England except certaine, ≈øtage plaiers, old women adicted to ≈øuper≈øtition, ≈øely hu≈øbands ouerruled by theire wiues and certaine Mal-contentes, and frequenters. of ordinaries, that de≈øpaire to obteiue preferment in this ≈øtate, and and only hope for honour and dignity in a newe worlde, there are but fewe papi≈øts, and all theire numbers & forces, if we re≈øpect the multitude of true Chri≈øtians, amounteth

Secondly they talke very idlely of the dignity of Engli≈øh papi≈øts. But they name no one man of that ≈øort, that either for his greate ≈øeruice in warres, or peace de≈øerueth any ≈øinguler commendation. Therefore they runne out into a long reher≈øall of matters forepa≈øt, and talke of theire aunce≈øtors ≈øaying, that they haue de≈øerued wel of this coÃÑmonwealth. But as well might the Moderne Romanes alledge the greate ≈øeruices and noble actes of Scipio, Paulus Aemilius, Sylla, Marius, Catulus, Cae≈øar, Cicero, Cato and others, or of the auncient Troyans, from whom they pretend to be de≈øcended. they commend their aunce≈øters al≈øo for theire loue & fidelitie vnto theire princes. But what is that to iu≈øtifie the Practi≈øes of late papi≈øtes both again≈øte his maie≈øtyes predece≈ø≈øors king Edward and Queene Elizabeth, and al≈øo again≈øte him≈øelfe both in Scotland, and ≈øence his comming in England? Be≈øide that, if they claym to be de≈øcended from tho≈øe rebels that oppugned king Iohn, and king Henry the 8, and ≈øought to bring them vnder the Popes mo≈øt greeuous yoke, and to depriue them of their crownes, it ≈øhall not procure them any greate honour with the people, or grace from the king. They ≈øay they are not degenerated in any poynt from their ance≈øters, and that they haue endcuoured to ≈øerue god, as theire forefathers haue done, euer ≈øince our countries conuer≈øion from pagani≈øme, and La≈øtly that no ≈øuffering recu≈øant euer lifted vp a finger to the lea≈øte dammage or detriment of his prinee or country. But theire ≈øayings are conuinced to bee mo≈øt vntrue both by publike records and common experience. for if wee re≈øpecte matter of religion we find, that they hold diuers poynts of doctrine confirmed in the late conuenticles of Lateran, Con≈øtance Florence & Trent, which were not known, nor heard of when this land was conuerted from pagani≈øme, nor long after. Likewi≈øe both their mi≈ø≈øals, and breuiarics, & their ma≈ø≈øes and formes of gods ≈øeruice are new, and not known of the ancient Britons and Engli≈øh. and papi≈øts haue been principall actors in mo≈øte of tho≈øe rebellions and trea≈øons that haue beene practi≈øed and intended again≈øt king Henry the 8. king Edward the ≈øixth, Queen Elizabeth, and his maie≈øty. Thirdly they runne out into a large di≈øcour≈øe of theire hard v≈øage in the late Queenes time, as they call it, and of the Queens proceeding again≈øt them, and of the effectes thereof en≈øuing, & pray the king to follow her rather in her, di≈øpo≈øitioÃÑ to mildne≈ø≈øe, then in her other hard and ≈øharp cour≈øes. Thirdly they fal≈øly coÃÑmeÃÑd her mild cour≈øes. & ≈øhew that troubles en≈øued of the exe quution of laws again≈øt papi≈øts, whereas in truth her re≈øolute cour≈øe a gayn≈øte theÃÑ ≈øecured her, & her ≈ølow exequutioÃÑ or rather ≈øu≈øpeÃÑfioÃÑ of penal lawes again≈øt papi≈øts cau≈øed troubles, rebelioÃÑs, trecherous practi≈øes & heaped ≈øorrows both vpoÃÑ her, & her true friends, &, I feare brought her to her end. fal≈øe premi≈ø≈øes, theire exceptions are di≈øproued, theire a≈ø≈øertions notoriou≈øly fal≈øe and rediculous. Fir≈øt they ≈øay they haue their vnder≈øtanding captiuated in ob≈øequium fidei (≈øcilicet papi≈øticae) by mo≈øt euident te≈øtimony of holy writ, of vnity, vniuer≈øality, ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, antiquity and authority

La≈øtly they ≈øeeme to haue theire braynes di≈øtempred, that are made to beleeue, that the popi≈øh ≈øacrifice of the ma≈ø≈øe for quick and deade, their carnall eating of Chri≈øts fle≈øh with the mouths of men, nay with the mouth of bruit bea≈øts, their tran≈øub≈øtantiation, halfe communions, and idolatrous wor≈øhip of the ≈øacrament, the popes vniuer≈øall and plenary power conteined in decretales, their 7. ≈øacraments, and doctrine of iu≈øtification by orders, mariage and extreame vnction, theyr wor≈øhip of ≈øaints, reliques, and images, and all the re≈øt of their abhominable doctrine may be proued by authority of ≈øcriptures, fathers, ≈øaints, doctors, councels, Parliamentes, and that the ≈øame is confirmed dy vnitie, vniuer≈øality, ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and. antiquity, be≈øide the te≈øtimony of virgins and Martyrs, This we may affirme of the Apo≈øtles creed, and the Catholike fayth taught and publi≈øhed in auncient Councels, but by no meanes of the fayth of the moderne ≈øinagogue of Rome. Secondly they alledge, that neuer any vniver≈øall innouation in matters of religion hath been made, but that the commi≈ø≈øion and vocation of the me≈ø≈øengers hath beene authori≈øed by ≈øignes and wonders. But this allegation, as it concearneth

div.p: THE Lords, no doubte, looked for thanks for their gentle and milde cour≈øe taken with the≈øe ma≈ø≈øepree≈øts. if they looked for none, yet his maie≈øty de≈øerued at their hands both thanks and prai≈øes, that gaue them life, who had ≈øo well de≈øerued death, and though he ≈øent them out of England; yet did ≈øend them into no place but whether they had fled before voluntarily of them≈øelues.
